He was admitted on 3-26 with urinary retention following a non-ST-elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI). During cardiac catheterization, the patient was found to have triple vessel disease (3VD) with LM ostial lesion, LCx, and RCA total occlusions. PCI for 3VD was deferred for CT surgery evaluation. The patient was initially chest pain-free but developed chest pain after rounds this morning, which resolved with nitroglycerin. A transthoracic echocardiogram (TTE) shows moderate regional left ventricular systolic dysfunction with inferior/inferolateral akinesis/hypokinesis and an ejection fraction of 40%.

Given the recurrent chest pain, emergent coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) surgery is being considered without full clopidogrel washout due to recurrent chest pain. The timing of surgery will depend on the international normalized ratio (INR). Additional tests ordered include a CT chest to evaluate the aorta and carotid ultrasound. Medications include continuing lisinopril (uptitrate to 40 mg daily), metoprolol, nitroglycerin for chest pain, holding coumadin pre-operatively, and continuing atorvastatin.
